questions.text: What are the three pillars of Scrum?
questions.explanation: Transparency, Inspection, and Adaptation are the empirical pillars supporting Scrum theory.

questions.text: Who is responsible for maximizing the value of the product?
questions.explanation: The Product Owner is accountable for maximizing the value of the product resulting from the work of the Scrum Team.

questions.text: What is the maximum duration of a Sprint?
questions.explanation: Sprints are fixed length events of one month or less to create consistency.

questions.text: Which meeting is held at the end of a Sprint to inspect the Increment?
questions.explanation: The Sprint Review is held to inspect the outcome of the Sprint and determine future adaptations.
The Scrum Master is responsible for ensuring that all Scrum events take place and are positive, productive, and kept within the timebox.

questions.text: What does the 'Definition of Done' ensure?

options.B: Transparency and quality of the Increment

questions.explanation: It creates a shared understanding of what work was completed and ensures the Increment meets the quality measures.

questions.text: Which artifact contains the ordered list of everything that is known to be needed in the product?
questions.explanation: The Product Backlog is an emergent, ordered list of what is needed to improve the product.

questions.text: The Daily Scrum is time-boxed to:
questions.explanation: The Daily Scrum is a 15-minute event for the Developers.

options.C: Sub-teams or hierarchies within the Developers

questions.explanation: Scrum recognizes no titles for Developers, and no sub-teams like 'testing' or 'architecture'.

questions.text: Who has the authority to cancel a Sprint?
questions.explanation: Only the Product Owner has the authority to cancel the Sprint.

options.B: A measure of the amount of work a Team can tackle during a single Sprint
options.C: How fast the Product Owner speaks

questions.explanation: Velocity is a metric used to forecast how much work can be completed in future Sprints.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a Scrum Artifact?
questions.explanation: User Stories are a common practice but not an official Scrum Artifact defined in the Scrum Guide.
The Retrospective is for the Scrum Team to inspect itself and create a plan for improvements to be enacted during the next Sprint.

questions.text: Kanban differs from Scrum primarily by:

options.B: Focusing on continuous flow rather than fixed-length iterations

questions.explanation: Kanban emphasizes continuous flow and limiting work in progress (WIP), whereas Scrum uses fixed-length Sprints.
A burn-down chart is a graphical representation of work left to do versus time.
